A literature survey confirmed the lack of any report on the permeability of dammarane saponins. However, reports suggest that the other class of saponins, the steroidal saponins, can pass through Caco-2 monolayers. These saponins are actively transported by suitable transport proteins, such as sugar transporters, or can be effluxed across the monolayers by efflux pumps such as P-gp and MRP-2.
10, 32âˆ’ 36 We know that Caco-2 cells express active transporters including sugar transporters such as SGLT1 (responsible for the transport of glycosides),
31 GLUT2 and GLUT5.
10 Analysis of our permeability assay data in light of these literature reports suggests that the glycosylated saponins assessed here may be actively transported by sugar transporters across Caco-2 monolayers. The low permeability of saponins 13 and 15 may be attributed to the fact that these saponins are effluxed across Caco-2 monolayers by suitable efflux pumps such as P-gp and MRP-2. An inhibitory transport study can be used in the future to determine the specific transporters or efflux proteins that are involved.
